instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the backlight on the LCD screen, this is necessary to get the screen to light up..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No back light
threads.message: I had 8.5V at the boost circuit output, I have changed the backlight driver and wired the missing feedback line. When I connect the feedback wire input fuse is failing, Not sure why. I don't see any short at output

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No back light
threads.message:
So you get image, only missing backlight?
Post diode mode to ground at both pins of <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>; w/ and w/o LCD connected.

Any history available?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No back light
threads.message:
Voltages at diode mode with respect to ground 
Without display - 0.610V and 0.417V
With display - 0.607V and 0.416V

Be sure to connect feedback trace correctly.
And change <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>.

When I check <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> Gate - the 5th pin is 0V and the 2nd pin is 3.3V.

"I had 8.5V at the boost circuit output"
Impossible without that signal.
Fuse gets burnt again?

threads.message:
Now I can see both <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> are present and 3.3 V but <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> is not functioning I mean I get 0V at <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL>. And 8.3V at PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLTFET.
I don't have <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> MOSFETs spare. Am I allowed to connect <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_DIV_L</SIGNAL> directly to Ground for testing purpose?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No back light
threads.message: Yes, the problem solved, I have shorted the 1st and 6th pins of  <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>. Found the backlight is present. Then I have replaced the <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> with a new one. Now it's perfect. Thanks for the support

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No back light
threads.message:
Why not <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL>???
Bypass pins 1/3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No back light
threads.message: However the issue is resolved. Apparently the driver IC and <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> were faulty. Replaced both and it's working perfectly☺️

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No back light
threads.message:
So the backlight circuit works; 25V is correct output.

Try known good working LCD assembly.
If still no image, check diode mode to ground on all data video lines.
Also be sure all the caps are in place and have good traces.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No back light
threads.message: I have removed and connected the board , hdd and all the connections. Now good news is image and backlight is there. I suspect something were wrong with smc/Pram memory. The touchpad flex cable might had a short internally. I don’t want to try this broken cable anymore. Ordered new one. Waiting for it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No back light
threads.message: Yes, everything solved, Fan connecter was lost, Then I have removed and cleaned the display connector. Now the system works perfectly so far
